questions.text: In the neonatal intensive care unit, a premature newborn presenting with respiratory distress requires immediate resuscitation. The infant's weight is recorded at 1,500 grams. Given the critical need for precise and controlled ventilation in such a delicate patient, selecting the correct size of the Ambu bag (manual resuscitator) is essential. Which of the following Ambu bag sizes is most appropriate for the resuscitation of this premature infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 250 mL.

 

Option B: 250 mL.

 

Neonatal resuscitation requires proper equipment, including an Ambu bag, to deliver positive pressure ventilation to the newborn. The size of the Ambu bag is important, as it can affect the amount of tidal volume delivered to the infant.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: A 150 mL Ambu bag is too small for a premature infant weighing 1,500 grams. This size would not deliver enough tidal volume to effectively ventilate the infant.

 

Option C and D: A 500 mL and 750 ml Ambu bag may be too large for a premature infant weighing 1,500 grams. This size may deliver too much tidal volume, which can be harmful to the infant.

 

Educational objective:

 

The importance of selecting the appropriate equipment size in neonatal resuscitation to ensure effective and safe ventilation. Using a 250 mL Ambu bag for a premature infant weighing 1,500 grams is appropriate to provide the necessary respiratory support without causing injury to the infant's delicate respiratory structures.

 

Ref- O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 129-131.

choices.text: Suction the mouth & nose and start bag & mask ventilation

questions.text: A newborn girl is delivered via emergency cesarean section to a 34-year-old mother whose pregnancy was marked by hypertension and concerning fetal heart rate patterns noted during prenatal monitoring. At birth, the baby is observed to be coated in thick green meconium. Upon a thorough examination, the infant is found to be apneic, bradycardic, and displaying poor muscle tone. As the pediatrician on duty, you are tasked with initiating resuscitation. What is the first step you should take in the resuscitation process for this neonate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Suction the mouth & nose and start bag & mask ventilation.

 

Option B:

 

Ventilation is initiated after meconium is removed. The goal is to remove airway meconium and to prevent its aspiration into the small airways where ventilation-perfusion mismatch may occur with deleterious effects.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: IV bicarbonate cannot be used in this case, As the initial management is to maintain the airway.

 

Option C: Bag-and-mask ventilation can be initiated once the airway is cleared.

 

Option D: Chest compressions is indicated if the HR is less than 60.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clearing the airway of meconium through suctioning before initiating positive pressure ventilation is crucial in non-vigorous meconium stained baby to prevent meconium aspiration syndrome.

 

Ref- O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 129-131.

choices.text: Streptococcus pneumoniae
Neisseria meningitidis
Haemophilus influenzae
Staphylococcus aureus

questions.text: A mother brings her 3-year-old child presenting with fever, cough, and difficulty in breathing. On examination, the child has increased respiratory rate, decreased breath sounds on the left side, and dullness to percussion over the left lung field. Chest X-ray shows consolidation of the left lower lobe. Based on these findings, what is the most likely causative organism responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Streptococcus pneumonia

 

Option A:

 

The most likely causative organism in this case is Streptococcus pneumoniae, based on the clinical features and presentation of pneumonia in a young child.

 

The presence of fever, cough, and difficulty breathing, along with increased respiratory rate, decreased breath sounds on the left side, and consolidation of the left lower lobe on chest X-ray are all consistent with pneumonia caused by S. pneumoniae.

 

Treatment of S. pneumoniae pneumonia involves administration of appropriate antibiotics and supportive care to manage symptoms and prevent complications.

 

  • It is important to note that other bacteria, such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydophila pneumoniae, and Legionella pneumophila, can also cause pneumonia in children, particularly in older children and adolescents.
  • However, these bacteria typically present with atypical symptoms, such as headache, myalgia, and gastrointestinal symptoms, and may not show consolidation on chest X-ray.
  • Pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae is also called as The Walking Pneumonia wherein the patient is virtually asymptomatic.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Neisseria meningitidis, is a bacterium that causes meningitis and sepsis, but is not typically associated with pneumonia.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenzae, is a common cause of pneumonia in children, but has become less common since the introduction of the H. influenzae vaccine.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus can cause pneumonia in children but is typically associated with more severe infections and is less common as a cause of community-acquired pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common bacterial pathogen causing lobar pneumonia, particularly in children, and is associated with focal consolidation on chest X-ray and clinical findings such as fever, cough, and focal respiratory signs. Prompt recognition and appropriate antibiotic treatment are essential for managing bacterial pneumonia effectively.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-3087.

choices.text: Acute laryngitis
Acute tonsillitis
Acute epiglottitis
Acute pharyngitis

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-year-old child presenting with complaints of high fever, severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, drooling, and inspiratory stridor. On examination, the child appears anxious, has a muffled voice, and the following appearance. Based on these findings given, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Acute epiglottitis

 

Option C:

 

The most likely diagnosis in this case is Acute epiglottitis. The presence of high fever, severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, drooling, and inspiratory stridor, along with an anxious appearance, muffled voice, and a cherry-red epiglottis in the image are all consistent with acute epiglottitis.

 

  • Acute epiglottitis is a serious medical emergency that requires immediate treatment to prevent airway obstruction and respiratory failure.
  • Treatment of acute epiglottitis involves immediate airway management, such as intubation or tracheostomy, to maintain airway patency.
  • Antibiotics are also administered to treat the underlying bacterial infection causing the epiglottitis.
  • It is important to note that the use of oral examination or throat swab to diagnose acute epiglottitis should be avoided due to the risk of airway obstruction due to LARYNGOSPASM.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute laryngitis presents with hoarseness, cough, and mild throat pain, but lacks the characteristic symptoms and physical findings seen in acute epiglottitis.

 

Option B. Acute tonsillitis presents with sore throat, fever, and enlarged tonsils, but lacks the inspiratory stridor and cherry-red epiglottis.

 

Option D. Acute pharyngitis presents with sore throat, fever, and enlarged lymph nodes, but lacks the drooling, inspiratory stridor, and cherry-red epiglottis seen in acute epiglottitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute epiglottitis, a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by rapid onset of high fever, severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, drooling, inspiratory stridor, anxious appearance, and the presence of a "thumb sign" on lateral neck X-rays. Prompt recognition and management are essential to prevent airway compromise and respiratory distress.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition page 8702

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to the pediatric outpatient department with progressive writhing and jerking movements of the extremities, excessive drooling, and multiple joint pains. On examination, a brown-yellow pigment is noted around the iris. Despite an unremarkable CT scan, an MRI reveals bilateral hypodense areas in the basal ganglia. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of aspartate transaminase (AST) and alanine transaminase (ALT). Based on the clinical presentation and investigative findings, which gene is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ATP 7B in Chromosome 13

 

Option B:

 

The clinical features mentioned in the question is of Wilson’s disease and the gene responsible is ATP 7B gene which is located in Chromosome 13.

 

Symptoms:

  • Jaundice
  • Tremor
  • Personality change
  • Hallucination
  • Infertility
  • Joint pain
  • Physical exam
  • Hepatomegaly and splenomegaly
  • Asterixis
  • Chorea
  • Loss of coordination
  • Dementia
  • Pathognomonic Kayser-Fleischer Rings 

 

Diagnosis:

  • liver biopsy not always indicated
  • copper studies
  • ↓ serum ceruloplasmin and ↓ serum copper
  • 24-hour urinary copper ↑ excretion
  • AST:ALT ratio usually > 2

 

Treatment

  • First-line -d-penicillamine
  • Chelating agent to remove excess copper
  • Co-administer with pyridoxine
  • Oral zinc.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. ATP 7A on Chromosome 13: Mutations in the ATP7A gene cause Menkes disease, a condition characterized by copper deficiency, leading to neurological degeneration, kinky hair, and growth failure, which is not consistent with the patient's presentation.

 

Option C. ATP 13B on Chromosome 7 & D. ATP 13A on Chromosome 7: There are no well-documented diseases directly associated with mutations in ATP 13B or ATP 13A that match the clinical features described in the question. These options are included as distractors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wilson's disease, an autosomal recessive disorder affecting copper metabolism, leading to copper accumulation in tissues. This condition is characterized by neurological symptoms (such as writhing and jerking movements), psychiatric disturbances, Kayser-Fleischer rings (the brown-yellow pigment around the iris), and liver dysfunction (elevated AST and ALT). The disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene located on Chromosome 13, which encodes a protein essential for copper transport and excretion.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition Page No- 1940.

choices.text: It is due to the mutation in the gene responsible for collagen
Superotemporal dislocation of lens can be seen
Child will present with features of tall stature and joint hypermobility
Can be associated with Cardiac abnormalities

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric department by her mother, who is concerned about the child's delayed developmental milestones, hypermobility, and frequent dislocations of her shoulders and knees. Upon examination, the pediatrician also notes decreased visual acuity and suspects a condition related to a protein defect with an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. Which of the following statements about the suspected disease is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It is due to the mutation in the gene responsible for Collagen

 

Option A:

 

The diagnosis based on the clinical history given is the Marfan’s syndrome.

 

Marfan's syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting the connective tissue, resulting from mutations in the FBN1 (fibrillin-1) gene. Fibrillin-1 is a glycoprotein that is essential for the formation of elastic fibres found in connective tissue. It primarily affects the skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular systems.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Superotemporal dislocation of the lens: This is true for Marfan syndrome. Lens dislocation (ectopia lentis) is a common ocular manifestation, with the lens typically dislocating in a superotemporal direction.  Other Ocular manifestations can include near-sightedness and retinal detachment.

 

Option C: Tall stature and joint hypermobility: Patients with Marfan syndrome often present with a tall stature, long limbs, and joint hypermobility, which are characteristic features of the condition. May include a curved spine, and chest deformities such as pectus excavatum. Patients may also experience joint hypermobility.

 

Option D: Cardiac abnormalities: Marfan syndrome can be associated with various cardiac issues, most notably aortic dilatation and dissection (aortic aneurysms), which are significant causes of morbidity and mortality in affected individuals.

Early diagnosis and careful monitoring are crucial to managing the condition and preventing severe complications. Treatment options focus on symptom management and surgical interventions if necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marfan syndrome, which is indeed due to a mutation in the FBN1 gene responsible for the production of fibrillin-1, not collagen.

 

Ref- Nelson 20th Edition, Page No- 618-619

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to a pediatric outpatient department in a tertiary care hospital in India by his mother, who is concerned that her son has never passed urine from the tip of his penis. The child has otherwise been healthy with no significant medical history. On physical examination, the urethral orifice is not located at the usual position at the tip of the penis. The rest of the genital examination shows normal testicular descent and no other abnormalities.

Which among the following is the most common congenital urethral anomaly?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypospadias

 

Option D:

 

Hypospadias is a congenital condition where the urethral opening is located on the underside of the penis rather than at the tip. It is the most common congenital anomaly of the penis, affecting approximately 1 in every 250 male births.

 

The characteristic features: The external meatus opens on the underside of the penis anywhere from just short of the normal site as far back as the perineum, while the ventral aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed (the ‘hooded prepuce’) and there is usually a ventral deformity of the erect penis.

 

Management typically involves surgical repair to extend the urethral opening to the tip of the penis, usually performed before the child reaches 18 months of age to facilitate normal urination and, in the future, sexual function.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Epispadias: This is a less common condition where the urethral opening is on the upper surface of the penis. It often presents with more severe anatomical anomalies and can be associated with bladder exstrophy.

 

Option B. Urethral stenosis: This involves a narrowing of the urethra, which can lead to difficulty urinating but does not involve abnormal placement of the urethral opening.

 

Option C. Bladder exstrophy: A rare congenital condition where the bladder and associated structures are exposed outside the abdomen. It is usually noticeable immediately after birth due to the visible bladder tissue and associated abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypospadias is the most common congenital urethral anomaly and management involves surgical repair.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No- 1063.

choices.text: Posterior urethral valve
Stricture of urethra

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-month-old male child with complaints of dribbling of urine and recurrent urinary tract infections. During her prenatal visits, the doctor mentioned abnormal radiographic findings, but she forgot about it due to the long gap since her last pregnancy. Upon reviewing her old medical file, you find the following ultrasound (USG) image. Based on the clinical features and the image provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior urethral valve.

 

Option B:

 

The image is suggestive of a keyhole appearance, which is seen in the case of Posterior urethral valves. Posterior urethral valve causes over distention of bladder with urine stagnation which leads to UTI and due to overdistention there occurs overflow dribbling in some cases.

 

  • PUV occurs in male child
  • Diagnosis is most commonly made antenatally with ultrasound,
  • USG demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder giving a key hole appearance.
  • Investigation will involve a voiding cystourethrogram, with the dilatation of the urethra above the valves demonstrable on a voiding cystourethrogram/ micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).
  • The bladder is hypertrophied and often shows diverticula.
  • Typically, there is vesicoureteric reflux into dilated upper tracts.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ureterocele: While ureterocele is a congenital anomaly involving the distal ureter, it typically presents with a cystic dilatation at the ureteric orifice within the bladder, rather than causing obstruction in the urethra. There will be an adder head or Cobra head appearance on IVP.

 

Option C. Urethral stricture: Urethral stricture refers to narrowing of the urethra due to scar tissue or inflammation. While it can cause urinary flow obstruction, it typically presents differently and is less common in infants.

 

Option D. Neurogenic bladder: Neurogenic bladder dysfunction is often associated with conditions affecting the central or peripheral nervous system, leading to abnormal bladder function. While it can cause urinary symptoms, the clinical presentation and imaging findings in this case are more suggestive of posterior urethral valves. This will show the Christmas tree appearance not the keyhole appearance.

 

Educational objective:

 

The clinical presentation of dribbling of urine and recurrent urinary tract infections in a male child, along with the history of prenatal radiographic findings suggestive of an abnormality, raises suspicion for posterior urethral valves (PUV).

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 555 Page No- From 10988.

questions.text: A mother brings her child with a history of narrow stream of urine for long days. She complaints that he often gets infected because of this. On examination, a suspicion of urethral stricture is made. All of the following are complications of urethral stricture except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urinary Incontinence

 

Option A:

 

Urethral stricture is characterized by narrowing of the urethra, often leading to obstructive urinary symptoms such as decreased urinary stream and difficulty initiating urination. While complications such as urethral calculi, bilateral hydronephrosis, and periurethral abscess are commonly associated with urethral strictures due to urinary stasis and obstruction, urinary incontinence is not typically observed. Instead, patients with urethral strictures commonly present with obstructive symptoms rather than urinary leakage.
 

Complication of urethral strictures are:

 

  • Urinary retention.
  • Urethral Calculi
  • Bilateral Hydronephrosis
  • Periurethral abscess
  • Urethral fistulas
  • Hernia and rectal prolapse.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Urethral Calculi: Urethral strictures can lead to urinary retention and stasis, predisposing to the formation of urethral calculi (stones).

 

Option C. Bilateral Hydronephrosis: Urethral obstruction caused by strictures can result in back pressure on the kidneys, leading to bilateral hydronephrosis due to dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces.

 

Option D. Periurethral Abscess: Urinary stasis caused by urethral strictures can predispose to the development of periurethral abscesses due to bacterial infection in the surrounding tissues.

 

Educational objective:

 

Urinary Incontinence is not a complication of urethral stricture, whereas urinary retention can be a complication of it.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 559 Page No- From 11076.

choices.text: Pain that improves with elevation of the affected testicle

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe pain and swelling in his scrotum. On examination, his right testicle is found to be tender, high-riding, and horizontal. A preliminary diagnosis of testicular torsion was made. Which of the following clinical features is most commonly associated with testicular torsion in children?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Absent cremasteric reflex

 

Option C:

 

Absent cremasteric reflex is the most commonly associated clinical feature with testicular torsion in children.

 

  • Pain may or may not improve with elevation of the affected testicle, while nausea and vomiting are nonspecific symptoms that can be present in many conditions affecting the genital tract.
  • Scrotal erythema and warmth are more commonly seen in infections such as epididymitis or orchitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pain that improves with elevation of the affected testicle: This is not typically observed in testicular torsion. Elevation of the testicle may worsen the pain due to further compromise of blood flow.

 Prehn’s sign positivity which is seen in case of Epididymoorchitis.

 

Option B. Nausea: While nausea can occur with testicular torsion due to severe pain, they are not specific to this condition and can be seen in various other causes of acute scrotal pain.

 

Option D. Scrotal erythema and warmth: Scrotal erythema and warmth may be present in cases of epididymitis or orchitis, which are inflammatory conditions of the scrotum, but they are not typically seen in testicular torsion.

 

Educational objective:

 

Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency characterized by the twisting of the spermatic cord, leading to compromised blood flow to the testicle.

 

Clinical features commonly associated with testicular torsion include sudden onset severe testicular pain, swelling, tenderness, and a high-riding, horizontal orientation of the affected testicle.

 

The cremasteric reflex, which normally causes elevation of the testicle upon stroking the inner thigh, is typically absent in cases of testicular torsion due to the compromised blood supply.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 560 Page No- From 11092- 11096.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought in by their mother due to fever and irritability. Notably, the child has a smaller head circumference than expected for their age. The mother recalls experiencing a mild, flu-like illness during her pregnancy. The histopathology examination of the same virus reveals the following cells. Given this history, clinical presentation and histopathology findings, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Congenital Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Infection

 

Option B:

 

Given histopathology image shows the typical owl’s eye appearance of CMV which are actually basophilic intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies due to the cytopathic effect of the virus.

 

(NOTE- This is in contrast with the owl’s eye appearance seen in the Reed-Sternberg cells of Hodgkin’s Lymphoma, which are actually eosinophilic intranuclear inclusion bodies with a background of inflammatory cells.)

 

CMV is a common viral infection that can be transmitted from a mother to her foetus during pregnancy.

 

Infants with congenital CMV infection may present with a range of symptoms, including fever, irritability, hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen)

 

The mother's history of a mild flu-like illness during pregnancy is a risk factor for acquiring CMV.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Congenital Rubella Syndrome: While congenital rubella can cause microcephaly, it is typically associated with additional features such as cataracts, heart defects, and hearing loss.

 

Option C: Congenital Syphilis: Congenital syphilis can lead to a variety of symptoms, including rash, hepatosplenomegaly, and bone abnormalities, but microcephaly is not as characteristic as in congenital CMV.

 

Option D: Congenital Toxoplasmosis: This condition can also cause microcephaly, but the mother's flu-like illness is more suggestive of a viral etiology like CMV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of microcephaly, fever, irritability, and the mother's history of a mild flu-like illness during pregnancy is suggestive of Congenital CMV Infection.

 

Ref: OP Ghai, Page No-264-265.

questions.text: A new mother is concerned about her 1-week-old infant who has been experiencing fever, poor feeding, and a vesicular rash on the face and trunk. She reveals that she had a similar rash during her pregnancy and at the time of delivery. The Tzanck smear of the lesion is shown below. Based on the clinical presentation of the infant and the mother's history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Congenital Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) Infection   

 

Option C:

 

  • Tzanck smear shows Acantholytic cells, multinucleated giant cells and eosinophilic inclusion bodies in HSV infection.
  • HSV is a common viral infection that can be transmitted from a mother to her foetus during pregnancy or delivery.
  • Infants with congenital HSV infection may present with fever, poor feeding, and vesicular rash on the face and trunk.
  • The mother's history of genital herpes during pregnancy is a strong risk factor for the diagnosis of congenital HSV infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Congenital Rubella Syndrome: Typically presents with cataracts, heart defects, and hearing loss, and not with the vesicular rash seen in herpes infections.

 

Option B: Congenital Cytomegalovirus Infection: Can cause a variety of symptoms, including hearing loss, microcephaly, and hepatosplenomegaly. While CMV can cause a petechial rash known as "blueberry muffin" spots, it does not cause the vesicular rash seen in herpes infections.

 

Option D: Congenital Toxoplasmosis: Often presents with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications, and does not present with vesicular rash characteristic of herpes infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Tzanck smear image showing multinucleated giant cells is indicative of herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. The presence of a vesicular rash in both the mother during pregnancy and the newborn, alongside the mother's history and the Tzanck smear findings, strongly suggests congenital herpes simplex virus infection. HSV can be transmitted to the infant during delivery if the mother has active genital lesions, leading to neonatal herpes, which can present with fever, poor feeding, and vesicular rash.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, page no 13283

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic in West Bengal, India, a mother brings her 9-month-old infant who recently experienced a high fever lasting three days, which then abruptly subsided. Following the resolution of the fever, the infant developed a rash that originated on the trunk and has now spread to the extremities. The rash is non-itchy, pink, and maculopapular. The infant appears in good health otherwise, with no significant irritability or feeding difficulties. Given the clinical course and the characteristic presentation of the rash, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Roseola infantum

 

Option C:

 

Roseola infantum also known aa Exanthem Subitum or The Sixth Disease

 

The most likely diagnosis for this infant is Roseola infantum based on the presentation of a high fever that abruptly resolved and now presents with a rash.

 

The rash typically starts on the trunk and then spreads to the extremities, i.e., centripetal in distribution

 

It is caused by the HHV 6 and HHV 7.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Measles: Measles presents with a high fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and coryza, followed by a rash that usually starts on the face and behind the ears before spreading to the rest of the body. The presentation in this case does not fit the classic measles progression.

 

Option B: Rubella: Rubella, or German measles, presents with a mild fever and a rash that also starts on the face and spreads downwards. However, rubella rashes tend to be finer and the disease is often accompanied by lymphadenopathy, which is not described in this case.

 

Option D: Scarlet fever: Scarlet fever, caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, presents with a sore throat, high fever, and a sandpaper-like rash that typically starts on the chest and abdomen. The sequence of fever followed by rash in the absence of sore throat or the characteristic sandpaper rash makes scarlet fever less likely in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Roseola infantum in infants is characterized by a high fever followed by a rash that starts on the trunk and spreads to the extremities after the fever resolves. This distinguishes it from measles, rubella, and scarlet fever, where the rash has different characteristics and is often accompanied by other specific symptoms.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-1594-1597.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child from Africa is brought by his parents for medical consultation, presenting with pronounced jaw swelling and ulceration as evident in the provided image. The child also exhibits difficulty breathing due to partial airway obstruction. A biopsy is performed, and histopathological analysis confirms a diagnosis of B-cell Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL). Based on the clinical presentation and biopsy findings, what is the most likely diagnosis, and which chromosomal translocation is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Burkitt’s lymphoma t (8;14)

 

Option D:

 

Burkitt’s lymphoma

  • Caused by the deregulation of the MYC gene on chromosome
  • EBV infection predisposes to c-myc translocation t(8;14)

 

Clinical features; BL is a rapidly growing tumor.

  • The endemic (African) form usually presents as a jaw or facial bone, loosening of teeth, tumor that spreads to extra nodal sites including the mesentery, ovary, testis, kidney, breast, and especially to the bone marrow and meninges

 

INVESTIGATION

  • CBC
  • RFTs and Serum electrolytes, uric acid, creatinine, calcium, phosphorus, Biopsy - histological Dx

 

Histology —

  • Cytologically, BL cells resemble the small non-cleaved cells within normal germinal centers
  • A "starry sky" pattern is usually present
     

Management

  • General management Prevent tumour lysis SDM
  • Rehydrate the patient
  • Allopurinol and Rasburicase.
  • Specific management; Cyclophosphamide, Vincristine, Prednisolone (CHOP)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkitt’s lymphoma, especially the classic presentation is of jaw swelling in African children, and its associated with the chromosomal translocation t(8;14).

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page number 6904

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with weight loss, fever, night sweats, and lethargy. Physical examination reveals a few firm, rubbery lymph nodes. A lymph node biopsy shows the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells, and subsequent PET CT identifies the involvement of four additional lymph nodes on the same side of the diaphragm as shown in the image. Suspecting Hodgkin's lymphoma, you proceed to stage the disease for treatment planning. Based on the information and evaluation provided, what is the stage of the lymphoma in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage 2

 

Option B:

 

HODGKINS LYMPHOMA:

 

It has bimodal distribution -15-19 and 5th -6th decade.

 

Clinical features:

  • Lymphadenopathy: lymph node-firm, rubbery.
  • Symptoms: unexplained fever, weight loss over 6 months (significant weight loss)  and drenching night sweats.
  • Lethargy, anorexia, pruritis (less common).

 

Diagnosis:Excisional biopsy.

 

HPE: Classical reed steen berg cell (owl eye inclusion body)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Stage 1: This stage is characterized by the involvement of a single lymph node region, which does not match the patient's findings.

 

Option C: Stage 3: Involvement on both sides of the diaphragm or additional extralymphatic organ involvement, which is not indicated here.

 

Option D: Stage 4: Diffuse or disseminated involvement of one or more extralymphatic organs, which is not indicated in the provided clinical scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on PET CT staging is done.

 

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter-161, Page No-4835-4840.

questions.text: During a bustling Monday in a pediatric clinic, you are tasked with overseeing the vaccination schedule amidst a heavy patient load. Amid administering various vaccines, you take the moment to educate your junior staff. You present them with a scenario to identify which vaccine listed is not sensitive to freezing and can be safely stored in a freezer.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MMR

 

Option D:

 

The MMR vaccine is not freeze-sensitive and can be stored in a freezer. It is a lyophilized vaccine that requires refrigeration after reconstitution but remains stable at freezing temperatures prior to that.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. DPT is a freeze-sensitive vaccine. If a DPT vaccine is frozen, the pertussis component can be denatured, rendering the vaccine ineffective.

 

Option B. IPV is also sensitive to freezing. Freezing can affect the potency of the polio vaccine, leading to a reduced immune response when administered.

 

Option C. Hep B is a freeze-sensitive vaccine. Freezing can cause the vaccine to lose its effectiveness, which may result in inadequate protection against the Hepatitis B virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Freeze sensitive vaccines include Hep B > HPV >DPT >DT > TT.

 

Freeze dried (Lyophilized) Vaccines are BCG, MMR, Measles, YF vaccine, HiB, JE

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 740

choices.text: Measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine
Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine

questions.text: A mother visits your clinic with her 14-week-old child for routine vaccination. Upon examination, the child appears active and exhibits normal growth parameters. Based on the child's age, which of the following vaccines is NOT recommended at this visit?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine

 

Option B:

 

Explanation:

 

At the age of 14 weeks, children are recommended vaccines - fIPV, Pentavalent including Hib, Rotavirus vaccine and PCV.

 

MR is administered at the 9 months of age.

 

So, Option A, C and D are given in the child of 14 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai Page No- 183-187.

questions.text: In the outpatient department, a new nurse from the Primary Health Center seeks clarification about the correct diluent to be used with a vaccine she has brought to you. The vaccine in question is shown in the image provided. What is the appropriate diluent for reconstituting this vaccine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Distilled water.

 

Explanation:

 

The given vaccine is the image of MMR, the diluent used in this case is Distilled water/ sterile water. It is important to use the correct diluent as provided by the manufacturer to ensure the vaccine's efficacy and stability.

 

Note - Use within 4 hours after reconstitution with diluent

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diluents - Normal Saline for BCG and Distilled/Sterile Water for Measles

 

Ref: OP Ghai Page No- 183-193.

choices.text: Fever and irritability- recommend Paracetamol for fever control.
Vomiting and diarrhoea- recommend increased fluid intake and oral rehydration therapy.
Rash and itching- recommend topical steroids for symptomatic relief.
Cough and congestion- recommend antihistamines for symptomatic relief.

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her infant son, Raghav, to the local clinic in rural India for his scheduled vaccinations. After receiving the oral live rotavirus vaccine, the mother inquires about potential side effects. The nurse, seeking to provide accurate information, turns to you and asks what the most common side effect of the rotavirus vaccine in infants is and how it should be managed. Which of the following is the correct response?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vomiting and diarrhoea- recommend increased fluid intake and oral rehydration therapy.

 

Option B:

 

The most common side effects following rotavirus vaccination are mild and include temporary vomiting and diarrhea. Management of these symptoms primarily involves preventing dehydration by increasing fluid intake and using oral rehydration therapy, especially in the Indian rural setting where intravenous therapy might not be immediately accessible. The use of oral rehydration salts (ORS) is common and recommended by health authorities worldwide for managing mild to moderate dehydration due to diarrhea.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fever and irritability may occur following many types of vaccinations and are generally managed with antipyretics like Paracetamol. However, these are not the most common side effects of the rotavirus vaccine.

 

Option C. Rash and itching are not typical side effects of the rotavirus vaccine and would not be the first concern following vaccination.

 

Option D. Cough and congestion are more commonly associated with respiratory vaccines, like the influenza vaccine, and are not typical side effects of the rotavirus vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common side effect of Rota vaccine in infants is vomiting and diarrhoea.
  • This side effect typically occurs within the first week after vaccination and resolves within a few days without any specific treatment.
  • However, the child should be monitored closely for signs of dehydration, such as decreased urine output, dry mouth, and sunken fontanelles.
  • The appropriate management of Rota vaccine-associated vomiting and diarrhoea is to increase fluid intake and provide oral rehydration therapy.
  • Oral rehydration therapy should be given to prevent dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.

 

Ref: OP Ghai Page No- 185-193.

questions.text: A concerned mother presents to the pediatric clinic with her child, who has experienced 7 episodes of loose stools from morning till evening. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes mild dehydration in the child. Considering the clinical presentation and the need for rehydration, which of the following is the most appropriate initial fluid choice for managing diarrhea in this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ORS

 

Option C:

 

The initial fluid of choice for diarrhea in an infant is ORS. Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) is the recommended first-line treatment for rehydration in infants and children with mild to moderate dehydration due to diarrhea. ORS is specifically formulated to contain the ideal balance of salts and sugars to facilitate water absorption in the intestines, effectively replacing lost fluids and electrolytes. Its composition aligns with the World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines for rehydration, making it highly effective in preventing and treating dehydration from diarrhea in children.

 

The cornerstone of acute diarrhea management is rehydration by using oral rehydration solutions (ORS).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Salt Water: While rehydration requires salt, salt water alone is not recommended due to its high sodium concentration, which can worsen dehydration and lead to hypernatremia.

 

Option B. Sugar Water: Sugar water can provide some energy but lacks the necessary electrolytes needed to correct the electrolyte imbalances caused by diarrhea. It is not sufficient for rehydration purposes.

 

Option D. Normal Saline: Normal Saline is an intravenous solution that can be used in more severe cases of dehydration or when oral rehydration is not possible. However, for mild dehydration and when oral intake is feasible, ORS is preferred due to its ease of use and effectiveness in promoting intestinal water and electrolyte absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) is the recommended first-line treatment for rehydration in infants and children with mild to moderate dehydration due to diarrhea. ORS is specifically formulated to contain the ideal balance of salts and sugars to facilitate water absorption in the intestine.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-289.

questions.text: A 17-month-old child is brought to a pediatric clinic in India for a routine eye examination. The examining physician notes a thinned-out cornea during the assessment. Further history reveals that the child has been diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia. The child's current weight is recorded at 10 kg. Considering the child's age and clinical findings suggestive of vitamin A deficiency, what is the appropriate dose of vitamin A supplementation for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2,00,000 IU

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features mentioned in this are suggestive of keratomalacia and the dose of vitamin A given in this child of 17 months is 2,00,000 IU.

 

 

keratomalacia

 

Vitamin A deficiency is characterized by night blindness and conjunctival xerosis. Bitot’s spots, Keratomalacia and fundus changes in severe cases.

 

Clouding of cornea in a child with Vit A deficiency is emergency → requires parenteral administration of 50,000 -100,000 IU Retinol

 

  • In keratomalacia → Local treatment with antibiotic drops & ointment, padding of eye → enhances healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Vitamin A deficiency:

 

<6 months of age Vitamin A 50,000 IU orally/dose

6-12 months of age Vitamin A 100,000 IU orally/dose

≥12 months of age Vitamin A 2,00,000 1U orally/dose

The same dose is repeated next day & weeks later.

 

Ref: Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 118.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to concerns about delayed dentition and poor growth. The child's diet is noted to be low in dairy products and vegetables. On physical examination, the boy is shorter than his peers, and his dentition is notably delayed. A wrist X-ray is performed, findings shown below.

 

 

Based on the clinical features and radiographic findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rickets

 

Option C:

 

The clinical presentation of delayed dentition, retarded growth, and dietary deficiency, along with the characteristic radiographic findings of metaphyseal widening, fraying, and cupping of the wrist, are highly suggestive of rickets. Rickets is a condition caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to impaired mineralization of bone and cartilage. In children, this can result in skeletal deformities, delayed growth, and dental issues.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteogenesis Imperfecta: This condition is characterized by bone fragility and is typically diagnosed based on a history of frequent fractures and blue sclerae. Radiographs would show thin bones with multiple fracture sites, not the findings seen in the provided image.

 

Option B. Scurvy: Caused by a deficiency of vitamin C, scurvy can lead to swollen, bleeding gums and bruising, but the radiographic signs would show 'scorbutic rosaries' at the costochondral junctions, not the metaphyseal changes seen in rickets.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis: This is a rare genetic disorder leading to abnormally dense bones, with radiographs showing increased bone density and bone within a bone appearance, which does not match the findings in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differential Diagnosis – based on Radiological findings

 

Rickets - Cupping and fraying of the metaphyses.

 

Osteogenesis Imperfecta - Thin bones with multiple fracture

 

Scurvy - 'Scorbutic rosaries' at the costochondral junctions

 

Osteopetrosis - Increased bone density and bone within a bone appearance

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page NO- 336- 340.

choices.text: Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
Giant cell tumor

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with a limp and localized leg pain worsening over two months. Examination reveals swelling in the mid-tibia without erythema or warmth. The X-ray finding shows below; and biopsy findings include cells with grooved nuclei, giant cells, and fibroblastic proliferation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

 

Option A:

 

The combination of clinical symptoms, X-ray findings of a lytic lesion, and the histological presence of grooved nuclei and giant cells is characteristic of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH). LCH is a rare disorder involving clonal proliferation of Langerhans cells, which are antigen-presenting cells that can affect various organs, including bone. In the bone, LCH often leads to lytic lesions and can present with localized pain and limping in children.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Giant cell tumor: This is more common in the epiphyseal region of long bones in young adults, not typically seen in children, and would usually present as a lytic lesion without the characteristic histological findings of LCH.

 

Option C. Chondroblastoma: Typically occurring in the epiphyseal plate of the long bones during childhood and adolescence, but the histological description does not match that of chondroblastoma.

 

Option D. Osteoid osteoma: This benign bone tumor usually presents with nocturnal pain that relieves with NSAIDs and would not show the histological features of LCH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis can present with a variety of symptoms depending on the organ involved, and when affecting the bone, it can lead to localized pain, swelling, and lesions that appear lytic on X-ray. Recognizing the unique histological features of Langerhans cells is critical for a definitive diagnosis.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page number 10,626

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to your clinic displaying symptoms of edema, irritability, and distinctive skin lesions. The mother describes the child's diet as being predominantly high in carbohydrates with a significant lack of protein. Laboratory findings reveal hypoalbuminemia and anemia. Based on the clinical presentation and the dietary history, what is the most probable diagnosis for this child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kwashiorkor.

 

Option B:

 

Kwashiorkor is the most likely diagnosis in this case based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.

 

Kwashiorkor is a form of protein-energy malnutrition that results from an inadequate protein intake but with adequate calorie intake. It is characterized by edema, irritability, skin lesions, and a swollen liver. Laboratory studies may show hypoalbuminemia and anemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Marasmus is a severe form of protein-energy malnutrition that results from prolonged inadequate intake of both calories and protein. It is characterized by severe wasting and malnutrition, loss of subcutaneous fat and muscle mass, and lethargy.

 

Option C. Rickets is a disease that occurs due to a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. It causes softening and weakening of the bones in children and can lead to fractures and deformities.

 

Option D. Scurvy is a disease that occurs due to a deficiency of vitamin C. It causes fatigue, muscle weakness, joint and muscle aches, and bleeding gums.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kwashiorkor is a protein-energy malnutrition disorder characterized by edema, irritability, skin lesions, hypoalbuminemia, and anemia, largely due to a diet deficient in protein but adequate in calories.

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 95-97.

choices.text: Mid arm circumference in 0-1year age group
Anemia detection in pregnancy
Height and weight calculated in < 5years age group

questions.text: While working in a primary healthcare (PHC) setting, you are tasked with assessing the nutritional status of the local community. You consider several parameters to evaluate the community's nutritional health. Which of the following parameters is NOT typically used to measure the nutritional status of a community?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mid arm circumference in 0-1year age group.

 

Option A:

 

Mid-arm circumference (MAC) is a useful indicator for assessing malnutrition in individual children, especially between the ages of 6 months and 5 years. However, as a community-wide indicator, it is not typically used alone to assess the overall nutritional status of the community. MAC is particularly valuable in settings where it is difficult to obtain accurate ages of children or to perform more comprehensive nutritional assessments.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Anemia detection in pregnancy: This is a common indicator used to assess the nutritional status of a community because anemia in pregnancy can indicate poor nutritional status among women of childbearing age and can have implications for the health of the community.

 

Option C. Childbirth weight < 2500 grams: Low birth weight is a significant indicator of the community's nutritional status as it reflects maternal health and nutrition during pregnancy, as well as the health and nutrition of the newborn.

 

Option D. Height and weight measured in children under 5 years of age: These are fundamental parameters for determining the prevalence of stunting and wasting, which are key indicators of chronic and acute malnutrition in a community.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MAC is assessed in 1- 5year age group

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

choices.text: Both can have mortality
Mortality in both cases will be less

questions.text:
A pediatric resident is presented with two contrasting cases of pediatric patients during their rotation. The resident is asked to assess which case would generally be associated with a higher risk of mortality without intervention.

 

 

Based on the clinical presentation, which child would typically be at a higher risk of mortality?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fatty Baby


Option B:

 

Kwashiorkor is associated with a higher immediate risk of mortality compared to marasmus. This is due to its complex metabolic disturbances, vulnerability to infections, and potential complications from edema affecting vital organs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differences between kwashiorkor and marasmus

 

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

questions.text: A healthcare provider is assessing a postpartum mother with a viral infection for breastfeeding suitability. Given the mother's diagnosis, the provider must decide if breastfeeding should be contraindicated. Which viral infection in the mother commonly requires temporary cessation of breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Herpes Simplex

 

Option C:

 

Herpes Simplex virus (HSV) presents a risk if the mother has active herpes lesions, particularly on the breasts. If there is an active HSV lesion on the breast, breastfeeding from the affected side should be stopped until the lesion has resolved to prevent transmission to the infant.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hepatitis B is not a contraindication for breastfeeding as long as the infant receives the appropriate vaccinations.

 

Option B: Hepatitis C is generally not considered a contraindication for breastfeeding. Transmission through breast milk is not common, and breastfeeding may continue unless there is nipple bleeding.

 

Option D: Varicella Zoster, responsible for chickenpox, is not a contraindication for breastfeeding if the mother has immunity before pregnancy or if the baby has received varicella zoster immune globulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While most maternal viral infections do not prohibit breastfeeding, certain conditions like active herpes simplex lesions on the breasts can necessitate temporary discontinuation of breastfeeding on the affected side to prevent the risk of neonatal transmission.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 1796

choices.text: Partially Acceptable, Affordable, Feasible, Sustainable & Safe

questions.text: During a session on infant feeding in areas with high rates of HIV, a public health specialist outlines the conditions that must be met for replacement feeding to be considered a suitable alternative to breastfeeding. These criteria are designed to ensure the safety and health of the infant where breastfeeding is contraindicated. What does AFASS stand for in the context of replacement feeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acceptable, Affordable, Feasible, Sustainable & Safe

 

Explanation:

 

Replacement feeding options should be Acceptable to the caregiver and family, Affordable within the family's budget, Feasible to implement consistently and correctly, Sustainable over time, and Safe from contaminants and pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To comprehend the AFASS criteria for replacement feeding, which ensure that non-breastfeeding options are safe and practical for infants who cannot be breastfed, particularly in contexts where HIV transmission risk must be minimized.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 1796

choices.text: Galactosemia
Active HSV of the breast
Both A and B
Only A

questions.text: A 30-year-old first-time mother has just given birth to a healthy baby boy and is eager to begin breastfeeding. She consults you for advice on starting breastfeeding. Knowing that breastfeeding can typically commence immediately following a normal vaginal delivery, you review her medical history and note she has untreated tuberculosis, which is a known contraindication to breastfeeding. Concerned for the well-being of both mother and child, you plan to discuss alternative feeding options. Based on this scenario, which of the following are also considered contraindications to breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both A and B

 

Option C:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Galactosemia in the infant is a rare genetic metabolic disorder where the infant cannot properly metabolize galactose, a sugar present in milk. Breastfeeding is contraindicated in infants with galactosemia because it can lead to serious complications, including liver damage, sepsis, and intellectual disability.

 

Option B: Active HSV lesions on the breast pose a risk of transmitting the virus to the infant during breastfeeding. If the lesions are present on the breast, direct breastfeeding is contraindicated to prevent neonatal herpes, a potentially severe infection in newborns. However, if the lesions are not on the breast, breastfeeding can continue with precautions, including covering the lesions and practicing meticulous hand hygiene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infant with Galactosemia and Active HSV of the breast are the contraindications of Breastfeeding.

 

Absolute contraindications to Breastfeeding are

 

  • HIV in the developed world
  • Active HSV of the breast
  • Mother on radiotherapy
  • Galactosemia
  • Chemotherapy drugs
  • Infant galactosemia

 

Relative contraindications

 

  1. Active untreated TB
  2. Active drug use (Meth, Cocaine, Heroin THC controversial)

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 3793-3794.

questions.text: An anxious mother brings her 8-year-old to the clinic due to abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding that started yesterday morning. Upon evaluation, the child displays signs of precocious puberty, café au lait spots, and fibrous dysplasia, leading to a diagnosis of McCune-Albright Syndrome (MAS). Considering the diagnosis, which endocrine anomaly is commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Rickets

 

McCune-Albright syndrome is a complex disorder involving mutations that affect the GNAS1 gene, leading to constitutive activation of the cyclic AMP pathway.

 

McCune Albright syndrome, has a triad of

 

  • precocious puberty
  • café au lait spots and
  • polyostotic fibrous dysplasia.

 

 

The endocrine abnormalities associated with this are

 

  • Hyperthyroidism,
  • GH excess,
  • Precocious puberty and
  • Rickets

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: While thyroid function can be affected in MAS, hypothyroidism is not a hallmark feature of this condition.

 

Option B. GH deficiency: Growth hormone deficiency is not typically associated with MAS. Instead, MAS can involve conditions like acromegaly due to growth hormone excess.

 

Option C. Delayed puberty: MAS is more commonly associated with precocious puberty rather than delayed puberty.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McCune-Albright Syndrome (MAS) is characterized by a triad of polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, café-au-lait skin pigmentation, and a variety of endocrine disorders, including precocious puberty, rickets, hyperthyroidism, etc.

 

Ref- OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-530

questions.text: A newborn is brought to you after the labor room nurse encountered difficulty in identifying the baby's gender, indicating a case of ambiguous genitalia. As you prepare to explain the situation to the parents, you consider the most common causes of this condition. What is the most prevalent cause of ambiguous genitalia in newborns?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

 

Option A:

 

Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) is the most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in newborns, particularly due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. CAH leads to an imbalance in steroid hormone synthesis, resulting in excess androgens, which can cause virilization of female genitalia or undervirilization of male genitalia, leading to ambiguous genitalia at birth.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Conn's Syndrome: Characterized by hyperaldosteronism, leading to hypertension and electrolyte imbalances, not ambiguous genitalia.

 

Option C. Adrenal Insufficiency: While adrenal insufficiency can present with electrolyte imbalances and possibly hypotension, it does not typically cause ambiguous genitalia.

 

Option D. Pheochromocytoma: A condition involving a tumor of the adrenal medulla that produces excess catecholamines. It is not associated with ambiguous genitalia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is the most common cause of the ambiguous genitalia in newborn.

 

  • Autosomal recessive condition,
  • Most common enzyme deficient is 21 Hydroxylase
  • Mutation of chromosome no 6.

 

Features of 21 Hydroxylase deficiency are

 

  • Ambiguous genitalia,
  • Salt wasting,
  • Dehydration,
  • Hyperkalaemia,
  • Hypoglycemia and
  • Shock.

 

Ref; OP Ghai Essential Pediatrics 8th Edition, Page No-526.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with a high-grade fever persisting for over 6 days, bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis, a diffuse macular rash on the trunk and extremities, and mucosal changes, including swelling and redness of the hands and feet. Considering these clinical findings, what is a common complication of the suspected disease in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Coronary artery aneurysm

 

Option C:

 

The child's symptoms are suggestive of Kawasaki Disease, a vasculitis that predominantly affects young children. A well-known complication of Kawasaki Disease is the development of coronary artery aneurysms, which can occur due to inflammation of the vascular endothelium, leading to vessel wall damage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aortic stenosis: This condition involves narrowing of the aortic valve, which is not a typical complication of Kawasaki Disease.

 

Option B. Mitral regurgitation: While valvular issues can occur in the context of vasculitis, mitral regurgitation is not a common complication of Kawasaki Disease.

 

Option D. Ventricular septal defect: This is a congenital heart defect rather than a complication of Kawasaki Disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kawasaki disease:

 

  • An acute febrile illness that primarily affects young children.
  • Clinical features include a high-grade fever that has persisted for more than 5 days, bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis, a diffuse macular rash on the trunk and extremities, and changes in the lips and oral cavity, including cracked lips and a strawberry tongue.
  • Swelling and redness of the hands and feet, known as "gloves and socks" syndrome, is also a common feature of Kawasaki disease.
  • The most serious complication of Kawasaki disease is the development of coronary artery aneurysms, which can lead to myocardial infarction, heart failure, and sudden death.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No. 5370.

choices.text: Bacterial meningitis
Tubercular meningitis
Fungal meningitis.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl named Malika is brought to the clinic by her mother with symptoms of acute fever and vomiting. The mother reports that the child has been avoiding loud sounds and bright lights from a recent family wedding by staying in her room for the past two days. During the examination, the child exhibits a sign that raises the suspicion of meningitis. A cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample is collected and analyzed, yielding the following results: lymphocyte count of 150 cells/mm^3, CSF protein level of 110 mg%, and CSF glucose level of 75 mg%. Based on the clinical features and CSF findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aseptic meningitis.

 

Option D:

 

Aseptic/ Viral meningitis is suggested by the presence of lymphocytic pleocytosis (elevated lymphocyte count in the CSF), an elevated protein level, and a normal glucose level in the CSF. These findings are consistent with viral meningitis, which is a common cause of aseptic meningitis. The child's avoidance of bright lights (photophobia) and loud sounds (phonophobia) along with the presence of fever and vomiting support this diagnosis.

 

Characteristic 

 

  • Kernig’s sign positive
  • CSF - raised lymphocytes, raised protein and normal glucose

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis:

Bacterial meningitis is often associated with a rapid onset of symptoms, including fever, vomiting, and signs of meningeal irritation such as neck stiffness.

  • The CSF findings in bacterial meningitis typically show an elevated white blood cell count (predominantly neutrophils), elevated protein, and decreased glucose levels. In this case, the CSF profile (lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and normal glucose) is not consistent with bacterial meningitis.

 

Option B. Tubercular meningitis:

  • Tubercular meningitis is a form of meningitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • The CSF findings in tubercular meningitis may show lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and decreased glucose. However, the clinical presentation and CSF findings in this case do not strongly suggest tubercular meningitis.

 

Option C. Fungal meningitis:

 

  • Fungal meningitis is rare and is usually seen in individuals with compromised immune systems.
  • The CSF findings in fungal meningitis may include lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and normal to mildly decreased glucose. However, the clinical presentation and CSF findings in this case are not highly suggestive of fungal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aseptic meningitis refers to non-bacterial, non-tubercular, and non-fungal causes of meningitis. Viral infections are the most common cause of aseptic meningitis.
  • The CSF findings in aseptic meningitis often include lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and normal glucose.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 6852

choices.text: There will be marginal change in the CSF production
Any sport which has adrenergic rise has no correlation with CSF production
Stimulation of the adrenergic system diminishes CSF production, whereas excitation of the cholinergic nerves may double the normal CSF production rate.
Excitation of the cholinergic nerves will decrease the normal CSF production rate.

questions.text: While enjoying a day at the theme park, a medical student observes a 2-year-old child eager to go on a thrilling ride. This scene prompts the student to reflect on a recent discussion regarding the effects of various activities on cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) production. By the end of the ride, characterized by excitement and potentially an adrenergic response, what change in CSF production might be expected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stimulation of the adrenergic system diminishes CSF production, whereas excitation of the cholinergic nerves may double the normal CSF production rate.

 

Option C:

 

The autonomic nervous system influences CSF production. Stimulation of the adrenergic system, which may occur during intense activities or stress (Fight or Flight Stimuli such as riding a roller coaster), has been shown to reduce CSF production. Conversely, activation of the cholinergic system can increase CSF production. This is due to the influence these systems have on the choroid plexus epithelium, where CSF is produced.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. There will be marginal change in the CSF production: The statement does not provide information about the specific activities or conditions that might affect CSF production.

 

Option B. Any sport which has adrenergic rise has no correlation with CSF production: The statement is overly general and doesn't accurately reflect the relationship between adrenergic activity and CSF production.

 

Option D. Excitation of the cholinergic nerves will decrease the normal CSF production rate: While it correctly states the impact of cholinergic stimulation on CSF production, it doesn't provide a complete picture of the adrenergic system's effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenergic stimulation reduces CSF production, while cholinergic excitation may double it.

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-578.

choices.text: Café au lait macules
Axillary freckling
These are small circular spots on the skin that are darker than the surrounding skin because of deposits of melanin
Both B and C are true.

questions.text: A mother presents her child for evaluation, concerned about skin findings in the axilla. She mentions that the child's father also has similar skin changes and is known to have a neurocutaneous disorder. Upon examination, you observe the findings shown in the image. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both B and C are true.

 

Option D:

 

The image shows axillary freckling, also known as Crowe's sign, which is characterized by small, dark spots in the axillary region. These spots occur due to increased melanin and are considered a diagnostic criterion for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). NF1 is a neurocutaneous disorder that can present with multiple dermatological findings, including café au lait macules and axillary freckling.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Café au lait macules: While café au lait macules are associated with neurofibromatosis, the spots in the axilla shown in the image are consistent with axillary freckling, not café au lait macules.

 

Option B. Axillary freckling: This option is correct; the findings are indeed axillary freckling, which is associated with neurofibromatosis.

 

Option C. These are small circular spots on the skin that are darker than the surrounding skin because of deposits of melanin: This description is accurate and describes the axillary freckling observed in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clinical diagnosis of NF1

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No-12251

choices.text: Hyperactivity and impulsivity
Intellectual disability
Hypersensitivity to sensory input
Rapid language acquisition

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother, who is concerned about his delayed speech development and lack of social interactions. She reports that he does not respond when his name is called, avoids making eye contact, and prefers to play alone. The child has a particular interest in lining up his toy cars and becomes extremely upset with any change in routine. His play is repetitive, and he shows little interest in playing with other children. On examination, the pediatrician notes that the child does not follow pointing gestures and does not point at objects to show interest. Based on the clinical presentation, the pediatrician suspects autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Which of the following is a common clinical feature of ASD?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypersensitivity to sensory input

 

Option C:

 

Hypersensitivity to sensory input is a common feature in individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Many children with ASD have unusual responses to sensory stimuli. This can manifest as hypersensitivity (over-responsiveness) or hyposensitivity (under-responsiveness) to sensory inputs like sounds, lights, textures, or smells. This sensory processing issue can contribute to behaviors such as avoiding loud environments, disliking being touched, or being fascinated by certain visual stimuli.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hyperactivity and impulsivity - These symptoms are more characteristic of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) than ASD. Although some children with ASD can display hyperactivity and impulsivity, these are not core features of ASD.

 

Option B. Intellectual disability - While some individuals with ASD may also have intellectual disability, it is not a defining characteristic of ASD. Intellectual abilities in individuals with ASD can range from superior to severely challenged.

 

Option D. Rapid language acquisition - This is not typically associated with ASD. In fact, individuals with ASD often experience delays in language development, and some may not develop significant spoken language.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ASD is characterized by challenges in social communication, repetitive behaviors, and in some cases, unusual responses to sensory stimuli, such as hypersensitivity or hyposensitivity. Recognizing these features is crucial for early diagnosis and intervention, which can significantly improve outcomes for children with ASD.

 

Ref: O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 56.

choices.text: Watersons shunt: PA is joined to ascending aorta
Potts shunt: PA is joined to descending aorta
Modified Blalock-Taussig Shunt: Subclavian artery is joined to pulmonary artery
Potts shunt: PA is joined to ascending aorta.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child with a history of cyanotic heart disease is brought to the pediatric surgery outpatient department by their mother. The pediatric surgeon conducts a thorough examination and then engages in a teaching moment with the residents, discussing the various shunt surgeries available for managing such conditions. The surgeon presents several options and asks the residents to identify which statement about shunt surgeries is incorrect, emphasizing the need for precision in understanding and choosing the appropriate surgical intervention.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Potts shunt: PA is joined to ascending aorta

 

Option D:

 

Potts shunt actually involves the anastomosis between the pulmonary artery and the descending aorta, not the ascending aorta. This shunt is used to increase pulmonary blood flow in certain types of congenital heart defects. By connecting the left pulmonary artery to the descending aorta, blood flow to the lungs is increased, which can improve oxygenation in patients with cyanotic heart disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Watersons shunt: This is accurate as it describes connecting the right pulmonary artery to the ascending aorta, a method used to augment pulmonary blood flow in specific heart conditions.

 

Option B. Potts shunt: This correctly identifies the traditional Potts shunt connection between the left pulmonary artery and the descending aorta.

 

Option C. Modified Blalock-Taussig Shunt: This accurately describes the connection between the subclavian artery and the pulmonary artery, a common procedure to increase pulmonary blood flow in cyanotic heart diseases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shunt surgeries are used in the palliative care in case of TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot). These surgeries include:

 

  1. Waterstons shunt: PA is joined to ascending aorta

  2. Potts shunt: PA is joined to descending aorta

  3. Modified Blalock-Taussig Shunt: Subclavian artery is joined to pulmonary artery

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition page 9234

choices.text: Ductus arteriosus undergoes physiological closure in 10-15 hours of birth
Fetus has 2 umbilical arteries and 1 umbilical vein
Ligamentum teres is formed from the Right umbilical vein
Foramen ovale closes to form Fossa ovalis

questions.text: As a new member of the pediatric department, you join a group of colleagues in the cafeteria who are discussing the nuances of fetal circulation. During the conversation, one of the colleagues poses a series of statements about fetal circulation for you to consider. Which of the following statements made by her is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ligamentum teres is formed from the Right umbilical vein

 

Option C:

 

The ligamentum teres, also known as the round ligament of the liver, is actually formed from the obliterated left umbilical vein, not the right. In fetal circulation, the right umbilical vein typically degenerates and is not present in the mature fetal circulatory system.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ductus arteriosus: This statement is true. The ductus arteriosus typically undergoes functional closure within the first 10-15 hours after birth due to increased oxygen levels and decreased levels of prostaglandins.

 

Option B. Umbilical vessels: This is a true statement. The fetus has two umbilical arteries that carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta and one umbilical vein that carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.

 

Option D. Foramen ovale: This statement is true. The foramen ovale generally closes functionally soon after birth and anatomically over several months to become the fossa ovalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ligamentum teres hepatis is formed from the Left Umbilical Vein and not the Right.

 

Mnemonic: Remember only LEFT (umbilical vein) is LEFT.

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition.page 9258

questions.text: A 28-week-old preterm girl, weighing 1100 grams, is being cared for in the NICU. After an initially stable period, she starts showing signs of respiratory distress characterized by tachypnea and mild subcostal retractions on day 6, along with widened pulse pressure. There is no cyanosis, but a continuous murmur is noted along the left sternal border during auscultation. The chest X-ray reveals pulmonary congestion. To alleviate her symptoms, which of the following medications should be administered?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Indomethacin

 

Option C:

 

The clinical presentation, including respiratory distress, widened pulse pressure, a continuous murmur, and pulmonary congestion in a preterm infant, suggests a diagnosis of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

 

Indomethacin, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), is often used to encourage the closure of the PDA in preterm infants by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis, which is responsible for keeping the ductus arteriosus open.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dexamethasone: While dexamethasone is used in the management of bronchopulmonary dysplasia and to reduce inflammation, it is not the first choice for managing PDA.

 

Option B. Racemic Epinephrine: Typically used for its bronchodilator effects in conditions like croup, not for managing PDA.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Used in heart failure and certain arrhythmias but not the primary treatment for PDA in preterm infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) involves the persistence of the ductus arteriosus beyond the neonatal period. Most cases are asymptomatic, but a continuous murmur can often be heard in the left infraclavicular area. ECGs are typically normal, though large PDAs may show signs of left ventricular loading. Chest X-rays are usually normal, with large PDAs showing increased pulmonary vascular markings. Management includes catheter-based closure with a coil or device at around 1 year of age, or surgical ligation between 1–3 months for significant cases.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No. 404-405.

questions.text: A 24-month-old child is brought in by their mother for a routine pediatric check-up. The child appears to be developing normally and has recently started to engage in scribbling activities. The mother is curious about her child's developmental milestones and asks you, the pediatrician, about the age at which the child will be able to copy the figure shown to you, which is a circle. Based on your knowledge of childhood development, at what age can a child typically copy a circle?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3 years

 

Option D.

 

The ability to copy a circle is a developmental milestone that most children achieve by the age of 3 years. This activity requires fine motor skills, hand-eye coordination, and the cognitive ability to perceive and replicate shapes, which are typically not fully developed until this age.

 

Important milestones of a 3 years child

  • Rides tricycle
  • Knows his age and sex.
  • Stands momentarily on one foot
  • Repeat a sentence of 6 syllables
  • Draws a circle
  • Has a vocabulary of 250 words
  • Can dress or undress himself completely
  • Counts 3 objects correctly
  • Builds tower of 10 cubes
  • Can withhold and postpone bowel movement

 

Remember –

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 1 year - The child’s pincer Grasp develops by 1 year.

Option B. 2 years - The child starts making vertical and circular strokes by 2 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fine motor milestones development includes the following,

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51.

questions.text: A concerned mother visits your clinic with her 3-year-old child, worried about the child's inadequate growth. The child's medical history reveals a low birth weight, along with ongoing feeding difficulties and a poor appetite. Upon physical examination, you note several distinctive features: a prominent forehead, a small jaw, a narrow chin, and clinodactyly. These clinical findings, combined with the child's growth issues, lead you to consider a specific diagnosis. Based on the information provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Russell - Silver syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Russell-Silver Syndrome

 

Most cases occur sporadically, chromosome 11p15, maternal disomy of chromosome 7.

Possible risks include:

 

  • Metabolic syndrome.

  • Uterine and vaginal dysgenesis

  • Gonadal hypofunction or testicular cancer in males.

  • Low muscle mass or low bone mineral density.

  • Myoclonus dystonia (in people with chromosome 7-related RSS).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uniparental disomy (UPD) is when a child gets both copies of a chromosome from one parent. This can lead to conditions like Prader-Willi syndrome (if both chromosome 15s come from the mother) and Angelman syndrome.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 1696, 2987

questions.text: A working mother brings her 3-year-old child to the pediatrician’s office for a routine check-up. On evaluation child is small for her age with a beak-like nose, narrow face, and widely spaced eyes as shown in the image. The mother reports that the child has difficulty feeding due to a small jaw and mouth, and has been slow to reach developmental milestones. The pediatrician diagnoses this as a case of Seckel syndrome. All of the following are features of Seckel syndrome, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Macrocephaly

 

Option B.

 

Seckel syndrome is characterized by intrauterine growth retardation, postnatal dwarfism, and a unique facial appearance except for macrocephaly, which is not associated with Seckel syndrome and thus is the correct answer.

 

Clinical features of Seckel syndrome include:

  • Microcephaly: a circumference that is below the 3rd percentile for their age and gender.
