  • Intellectual disability:
  • Facial abnormalities: Features may include a beak-like nose, narrow face, and Micrognathia. The ears may be low set and rotated backward, and the eyes may be widely spaced and/or have a downward slant.
  • Skeletal abnormalities: Bones may be thin and/or abnormally shaped, and joints may be hypermobile.
  • Feeding difficulties
  • Other features:  heart defects, kidney abnormalities, and seizures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A, C and D are the features of Seckel syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seckel (SCKL) syndrome, sometimes called “bird-headed dwarfism,” is an autosomal recessive developmental disorder characterized by marked growth failure and mental deficiency, microcephaly, a hypoplastic face with a prominent nose, and low-set and/or malformed ears. Approximately 25% of patients have aplastic anemia or malignancies.

 

Note - There is broad genetic heterogeneity comprising at least 8 classifiable types: SCKL1, ATR mutation; SCKL2, RBBP8 mutation; SCKL3, maps to 14q21-q22; SCKL4, CENPJ mutation; SCKL5, CEP152 mutation; SCKL6, CEP63 mutation; SCKL7, NIN mutation; and SCKL8, ATRIP mutation.

 

Ref: Nelson 21th Edition, Page No 10133

choices.text: Both a and b

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric outpatient department due to concerns about his unusually tall stature and intellectual disability. The pediatrician notes several features suggestive of a genetic condition, including a long face, large ears, and hyperextensible joints. After a thorough examination, the possibility of fragile X syndrome is considered. The doctor explains to the mother that the condition might present more severely in future generations, a phenomenon attributed to the increase in the number of trinucleotide repeats. Which concept is the doctor referring to?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both A and B

 

Option A and B.

 

The severity of the disease will increase with further generation because of the increase in the number of Trinucleotide repeats of CGG, this is known as Shermans paradox or phenomenon of Anticipation and is seen in case of fragile x syndrome.

Cause: CGG repeats at FMR1 gene of x chromosome

 

Clinical features:

  • Tall stature
  • Intellectual disability
  • Macro-orchidism (only evident at puberty)
  • Autistic behavior.
  • Hyperextensible joints.
  • Elongated face and chin
  • Large ears.

 

Diagnosis:

 

DNA testing (CGG triplet repeats at FMR1gene with larger than 200 repeats).

 

Explanation:

 

Option C. Complete penetrance is seen in case of Autosomal disorders not in case of trinucleotide repeats.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anticipation describes the phenomenon where a genetic disorder becomes more severe or has an earlier onset as it is passed down through generations. This is due to the expansion of trinucleotide repeats (in this case, CGG repeats in the FMR1 gene) in each successive generation (a/k/a Sherman's paradox)

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition, Chapter 85– Page No 3050

choices.text: Positive pressure ventilation
Umbilical vein catheterization

questions.text: A newborn infant, delivered at 38 weeks of gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery, is observed to have inadequate respiratory effort and a heart rate below 100 beats per minute immediately post-delivery. The infant is also noted to be cyanotic and not breathing effectively. Upon being alerted, the neonatal resuscitation team arrives quickly at the scene. Considering the urgent need for neonatal resuscitation, what is the most appropriate initial intervention to undertake for this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Positive pressure ventilation

 

Option A: 

 

Positive pressure ventilation is the most appropriate initial step for neonatal resuscitation in cases where the newborn has poor respiratory effort, as in the clinical case presented. Positive pressure ventilation can help to open up the infant's airway, improve oxygenation, and increase the heart rate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Chest compressions are indicated in cases where the newborn has a heart rate of less than 60 beats per minute despite adequate ventilation. This is not the most appropriate initial step in the clinical case presented, as the heart rate is between 60-100 beats per minute.

 

Option C. Epinephrine administration is indicated in cases where the newborn has a heart rate of less than 60 beats per minute despite adequate ventilation and chest compressions. This is not the most appropriate initial step in the clinical case presented, as the heart rate is between 60-100 beats per minute.

 

Option D: Umbilical vein catheterization is not an initial step in neonatal resuscitation. It may be indicated later in the resuscitation process if intravenous access is needed for medications or fluids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal Resuscitation Algorithm-2015 update

 

 

Ref- O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 130.

choices.text: Epiglottitis and Strep pneumoniae
Tracheobronchitis and H. influenzae
Tracheobronchitis and Parainfluenza virus
Epiglottitis and H influenzae

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic by their mother due to a 4-day history of fever and noisy breathing, which has recently been accompanied by coughing. The symptoms have increased the mother's concern. Upon examination, the child is found to have an inspiratory stridor. An X-ray is performed, showing the image provided. Based on the clinical presentation and the X-ray findings, what is the likely diagnosis and the most common causative agent in a child who has been immunized?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tracheobronchitis and Parainfluenza virus

 

Option C:

 

The diagnosis based on the history and X ray findings are Tracheobronchitis and is most commonly caused by Parainfluenza virus.

 

Croup, also known as laryngotracheobronchitis, is a type of respiratory infection that is usually caused by the parainfluenza virus. The infection leads to swelling inside the trachea, which interferes with normal breathing and produces the classic symptoms of "barking/brassy" cough, inspiratory stridor, and a hoarse voice. Fever and runny nose may also be present.

 

“Steeple sign” suggestive of subglottic narrowing, seen in case of croup or Tracheobronchitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Epiglottitis and Streptococcus pneumoniae: Epiglottitis typically presents with a high fever, severe sore throat, drooling, and difficulty swallowing, with a child appearing much more toxic than one with croup. Streptococcus pneumoniae is more commonly associated with pneumonia and not a primary cause of epiglottitis.

 

Option B. Tracheobronchitis and Haemophilus influenzae: While H. influenzae can cause respiratory tract infections, the widespread use of the Hib vaccine has made it an unlikely cause of tracheobronchitis in an immunized child. Additionally, tracheobronchitis caused by bacteria would typically present with more severe systemic symptoms.

 

Option D. Epiglottitis and Haemophilus influenzae: This used to be a common pairing before the Hib vaccine became widespread. Epiglottitis presents with a high fever, drooling, difficulty swallowing, and a muffled voice, along with a characteristic "thumb sign" on lateral neck X-ray, not the steeple sign seen in croup.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fever, noisy breathing, and inspiratory stridor, show a "steeple sign" on X-ray, is diagnosed as croup (tracheobronchitis), commonly caused by the Parainfluenza virus in immunized children.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition –Chapter - 412 Page No-From 8702

choices.text: Posterior urethral valves
Prune belly syndrome

questions.text: A mother in India brings her 2-day-old son to the pediatric clinic with concerns of his condition at birth. She reports that her son has had constant leakage of urine from the lower abdominal region since delivery. On examination, the infant has a wide separation of the pubic bones and a visibly externalized bladder through the abdominal wall, as shown in the accompanying image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bladder exstrophy

 

Option C:

 

Bladder exstrophy is a complex congenital anomaly characterized by an everted bladder protruding through an opening in the abdominal wall, wide pubic diastasis, and continuous urine leakage from the exposed bladder. The clinical description and the image are pathognomonic for bladder exstrophy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Posterior Urethral Valves: This condition is an obstructive developmental anomaly in male infants, presenting with a distended bladder, difficulty with urination, and potentially renal damage. It would not present with an externalized bladder or pubic diastasis and typically leads to a range of symptoms from urinary tract infections to renal failure.

 

Option B. Vesicoureteral Reflux: It involves the backflow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and potentially the kidneys. While it can present with recurrent UTIs and may be associated with other congenital abnormalities of the urinary tract, it does not cause the anatomical changes seen in the image, such as an everted bladder and diastasis of the pubic symphysis.

 

Option D. Prune Belly Syndrome: Also known as Eagle-Barrett syndrome, it is characterized by a triad of abdominal muscle deficiency, cryptorchidism (undescended testes), and urinary tract anomalies. The abdominal wall is thin and wrinkled, resembling a prune, which is not consistent with the exposed bladder in the image. It does not present with bladder exstrophy but may include a range of urinary tract malformations and symptoms related to the urinary system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bladder exstrophy is a rare congenital anomaly where the bladder is open and exposed on the lower abdominal wall. It is due to failure of fusion of the lower abdominal wall and bladder during embryonic development.

 

Clinical features include a wide pubic diastasis, everted bladder neck, and urine leakage from the lower abdominal wall.  Surgical reconstruction is the mainstay of treatment.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 556 Page No- 11019 to 11022.

questions.text: A 9-month-old child presents with recurrent infections, fatigue, and bleeding episodes. The attending physician notes anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia on a complete blood count. Upon examination, the child exhibits features suggestive of Mucopolysaccharidoses. Considering the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, the physician considers diseases for which enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) is not enough to treat the condition as a single aid. Which of the following diseases cannot be treated with enzyme replacement therapy alone?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hunters disease

 

Option C:

 

Hunters disease (Mucopolysaccharidosis type II) cannot be effectively managed with enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) alone. This limitation arises because the currently available enzyme formulations do not cross the blood-brain barrier, rendering them insufficient for addressing the neurological aspects of the disease. This necessitates additional therapeutic approaches for comprehensive management.

 

All of the mucopolysaccharidoses are Autosomal Recessive in nature, whereas Hunters disease has X-Linked Recessive with a CAG trinucleotide repeat, CORNEAL CLOUDING IS NOT SEEN IN HUNTER DISEASE

 

Common Presentations of Mucopolysaccharidoses:

 

  • Mental retardation

  • Developmental delay

  • Severe behavioral problems

  • Corneal clouding

  • Coarse facial features

  • Short stature, short trunk

  • Skeletal irregularities

  • Hepatosplenomegaly

  • Cardiac disease

  • Retinal degeneration

  • Hair loss or Hirsutism

  • Coarse facial features (flat nasal bridge, thick lips and large tongue, Prominent forehead)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher's disease is treatable with enzyme replacement therapy using imiglucerase, velaglucerase alfa, or taliglucerase alfa, which are recombinant forms of the deficient enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

 

Option B. Hurlers disease: Although Hurler's disease also requires more than ERT due to its severe and systemic nature, if addressing specifically enzyme replacement efficacy, it can still be part of the treatment protocol alongside other interventions like hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

 

Option D. Fabrys disease: Fabrys disease can be treated with enzyme replacement therapy using agalsidase beta or agalsidase alfa.

 

Educational Objective:

Hunter's disease, a form of Mucopolysaccharidosis, requires treatment approaches beyond enzyme replacement therapy due to its neurological involvement, which ERT alone cannot address.

Enzyme replacement therapy is available for Gauchers disease, Hurlers disease, Fabrys disease and Pompes disease.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition, Chapter 107 Page No 3551
